div.l: A litle Iape that fell in oure Cite
Oure hoste aunswerd and seide y graunte it the
Nowe tell on̄ Roger and loke that it be good
For many a pastee hast thou letten̄ blood
And many a Iakke of Dovor hast thou solde
That hath be twyse hote and twyse colde
Of many a pilgrym̄ hast thou cristes curs
For of the ꝑpercile yet they fare the wurs
That they haue eten̄ with the stubbled goos
For in thy shoppe is many a flie loos
Nowe tell on̄ gentill Rogere by thy name
But yit y prey the be not wroth for game
A man̄ may sey full sothe sothe in game and pley
Thou seyst full soth quod Roger by my fey
But soth pley quaad pley as the flemmyng seith
And therfore henry Bailly by the feith
Be nowe not wroth ere we departe here
Though that my tale be of an̄ hostlere
But neủere the lesse y woll not tell it yit
But er we parte y wys thou shalte be quit
And there with all he lough and made chere
And seide his tale as ye shull aftur here
Incipit Fabula Coci
A prentise whilom̄ dwelde in oure Cite
Of a crafte of vitellers was he
And galand was he as a goldfynche yn the shawe
Broun̄ as a berye a ꝓpropre shorte felawe
With lockes blake kemde full fetously
Daunce he coude full well and Iolily
That he was clepid Piers Reveloure
He was as full of love and Paramoure
As is the hive that is full of hony swete
Well was the wenche that with hym̄ myght mete
Atte eủery bridale wolde synge and hoppe
He lovid bet the Taverne than̄ the shoppe
For when̄ eny ridyng was in Chepe
Oute of the shoppe thiddir wolde he lepe
